Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Does fine-scale habitat variation shape genomic diversity within populations?
Award.AbstractNarration:
To a casual observer, it is obvious that individual organisms of the same species often differ from each other in many traits. When methods to quantify genetic variation emerged half a century ago, researchers discovered a remarkable degree of genetic differences among individuals as well. While many theories have been proposed to explain why there is so much genetic variation, the relative importance of different processes that could generate this pattern still remain controversial. This project tests the hypothesis that a large amount of genetic variation within populations is maintained when individuals are spread across environments that vary at a fine spatial scale, with different alleles (alternate forms of a gene) favored in different environmental conditions. Specifically, whole genome sequencing will be used to examine how levels of genetic variation differ in plant-feeding insects allowed to live and feed on a single species of plant (non-variable environment) versus multiple plant species (variable environment) in laboratory experiments. Additionally, genome sequencing of insects from natural populations will be conducted to infer if feeding on multiple plant species maintains genetic diversity within insect populations in nature. The goal of the project is to determine not only the extent to which environmental variation can maintain genetic variation within insect populations, but also which genes allow insects to adapt to diets consisting of different plants.

Genetic variation in natural insect populations enables rapid adaptation to novel diets or environments. These rapid adaptations, which can allow insects to acquire resistance to insecticides and feed on pest-resistant crop breeds, can have dramatic consequences for agriculture and public health, since insects are major crop pests and vectors of human disease. The goal of this project, understanding how genetic variation in insects is generated and maintained, is important for predicting when and how rapid adaptation occurs in insects. In addition, knowledge gained from this project will have broad relevance for understanding the outcomes of species interactions in natural ecosystems, as insects comprise half of all terrestrial animal species on Earth. Lastly, researchers will mentor undergraduate and high school students from underrepresented groups in science in the collection, interpretation, and public communication of data from this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Genetic variation -- defined as genetic differences between individual organisms from the same species -- plays a central role in evolution. Evolutionary change occurs when one form of a gene ("allele") is favored over others in a given environment, leading to changes in allele frequencies. Without genetic variation, evolution cannot occur.

The potential for populations to evolve rapidly, facilitated by high standing levels of genetic variation within populations, is widely appreciated by biologists. Understanding why populations harbor so much genetic variation remains a key goal in evolutionary biology. It also has major implications for medicine and agriculture: rapid evolution of drug resistance by pathogens and pesticide resistance by insects and weeds, for example, is enabled by genetic variation and can cause damaging pest or disease outbreaks.

In this project, we investigated the theory that environmental variation maintains genetic variation within populations. Specifically, if different alleles of a gene are favored in different habitats, we expect that multiple alleles will be maintained within a population spread across those habitats. We employed an integrative approach combining field and lab experiments with genome sequencing to test this prediction. Our study system consisted of a plant-feeding fly (Scaptomyza flava), for which we previously sequenced the genome, and two common mustard plant species (rocket mustard and tower mustard) that it feeds on. These plant species can be viewed as different habitats for the fly. Consequently, we epected that the fly population would contain a mixture of alleles enabling the fly to feed more efficiently on rocket mustard or on tower mustard.

In line with our prediction, we found that fly populations could rapidly adapt to feeding rocket mustard or tower mustard. We are currently analyzing extensive genome sequencing data (the equivalent of 100 human genomes of sequence data) to identify the genes responsible for this process. Overall, our findings are shedding light on how environmental variation shapes patterns of genetic variation in populations, how that variation enables rapid evolution, and what genes are most affected by this process. Because our study is conducted using a plant-feeding insect and relatives of mustard crop plants, the findings are relevant not only to our understanding of the evolutionary process, but also for predicting and preventing rapid evolution of crop pests.

In addition to the scientific merit of our project, funding by NSF facilitated efforts to train young scientists and communicate our research findings. The leaders of the project, a graduate student and a professor, trained six undergraduate students at the University of Arizona and two high school students at Tucson High Magnet School. Students received training in designing scientific experiments and reading scientific literature, and they helped conduct the research under close supervision by the project leaders. At least five of the students are now pursuing higher eduction or careers in science and medicine. The graduate student is now pursuing a post-doctoral career in genetics research. Together, the professor and the graduate, undergraduate, and high school students authored five papers published in scientific journals (with at least three more on the way) and presented their findings in eleven poster or oral presentations at scientific conferences.

Overall, funding by the NSF for this project has shed new insight into the processes that maintain genetic variation and enable rapid evolution (with direct relevance to agriculture and crop protection), enabled training of young scientists, and produced publications and presentations disseminating the findings to the scientific community and general public.
